items.title: Document title
items.help_text: The title of the metadata document (which will usually be the same as the element "Title" in the "Document description / Title statement" section). The metadata document is the metadata file (XML or JSON file) that is being generated.

items.title: Document ID
items.help_text: A unique identifier for the metadata document. This identifier must be unique in the catalog where the metadata are intended to be published. Ideally, the identifier should also be unique globally. This is different from the "Primary ID" in section "Document description / Title statement", although it is good practice to generate identifiers that establish a clear connection between these two identifiers. The Document ID could also include the metadata document version identifier. For example, if the "Primary ID" of the publication is “978-1-4648-1342-9”, the Document ID could be “IHSN_978-1-4648-1342-9_v1.0” if the metadata are produced by the IHSN and if this is version 1.0 of the metadata. Each organization should establish systematic rules to generate such IDs. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. The identifier may not contain blank spaces.

items.title: Metadata producers

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the person or organization who produced the metadata or contributed to its production.

props.title: Abbreviation
props.help_text: The abbreviation (or acronym) of the organization that is referenced in "Name".

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the person or organization mentioned in "Name".

props.title: Role
props.help_text: The specific role of the person or organization mentioned in "Name" in the production of the metadata.

items.help_text: The metadata producer is the person or organization with the financial and/or administrative responsibility for the processes whereby the metadata document was created. This is a "Recommended" element. For catalog administration purposes, information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful.

items.title: Production date
items.help_text: The date the metadata on this document was produced (not distributed or archived), preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYY-MM). A validation rule can be set in user templates to enforce a date format. This is a "Recommended" element, as information on the producer and on the date of metadata production is useful for catalog administration purposes.

items.title: Version
items.help_text: The version of the metadata document (not the version of the publication, report, or other resource being documented).

items.title: Primary ID
items.help_text: A unique identifier of the document. The "Primary ID" (also referred to as IDNO) is a unique identification number used to identify the database. A unique identifier is required for cataloguing purpose, so this element is declared as "Required". The identifier will allow users to cite the indicator/series properly. The identifier must be unique within the catalog. Ideally, it should also be globally unique; the recommended option is to obtain a Digital Object Identifier (DOI) for the study. Alternatively, the "Primary ID" can be constructed by an organization using a consistent scheme. Note that the schema allows you to provide more than one identifier for a same study (in element "Other identifiers"); a catalog-specific identifier is thus not incompatible with a globally unique identifier like a DOI. A validation rule can be set (using a regular expression) in user templates to enforce a specific ID format. The identifier may not contain blank spaces.

items.title: Other identifiers
items.help_text: This element is used to enter document identifiers (IDs) other than the catalog ID entered in the "Primary ID" (IDNO). It can for example be a Digital Object Identifier (DOI), an International Standard Book Number (ISBN), or an International Standard Serial Number (ISSN). The "Primary ID" can be repeated here (the "Primary ID" does not provide a "Type" parameter; if a DOI, ISBN, ISSN, or other standard reference ID is used as primary ID, it is recommended to repeat it here with the identification of its type).

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of identifier, for example "DOI", "ISBN", or "ISSN".

props.title: Identifier
props.help_text: The identifier itself.

items.title: Title
items.name: title
items.help_text: The title of the book, report, paper, or other document. Pay attention to the use of capitalization in the title, to ensure consistency across documents listed in your catalog. Pay attention to the consistent use of capitalization in the title. It is recommended to use sentence capitalization.

items.title: Subtitle
items.help_text: The document subtitle can be used when there is a need to distinguish characteristics of a document. Pay attention to the consistent use of capitalization in the subtitle.

items.title: Alternate title
items.help_text: An alternate version of the title, possibly an abbreviated version. For example, the World Bank’s World Development Report is often referred to as the WDR; the alternate title for the “World Development Report 2021” could then be “WDR 2021”.

items.title: Translated title
items.help_text: A translation of the title of the document. Special characters should be properly displayed, such as accents and other stress marks or different alphabets.

items.title: Date created
items.help_text: The date, preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM or YYYY), when the document was produced. This can be different from the date the document was published, made available, and from the temporal coverage.

items.title: Date published
items.help_text: The date, preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM or YYYY), when the document was published.

items.title: Date last modified
items.help_text: The date, preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM or YYYY) when the document was last modified.

items.title: Date available
items.help_text: The date, preferably entered in ISO 8601 format (YYYY-MM-DD or YYYY-MM or YYYY), when the document was made available. This is different from the date it was published. This element will not be used frequently.

items.title: Authors
items.help_text: The authors should be listed in the same order as they appear in the source itself, which is not necessarily alphabetical.

props.title: First name
props.help_text: The first name of the author.

props.title: Initial
props.help_text: The initials of the author.

props.title: Last name
props.help_text: The last name of the author.

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the author.

props.title: Author ID
props.help_text: Unique identifier of an author, which may be provided by services like ORCID or other

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of ID, i.e. the identification of the registry that assigned the author's identifier, for example "ORCID".

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The ID of the author in the registry mentioned in `type`.

items.title: Editors
items.help_text: If the source is a text within an edited volume, it should be listed under the name of the author of the text used, not under the name of the editor. The name of the editor should however be provided in the bibliographic citation, in accordance with a reference style. The element has four sub-elements: first name of the editor, initials of the editor, last name of the editor, and affiliation of the editor.

props.title: First name
props.help_text: The first name of the editor.

props.title: Initial
props.help_text: The initials of the editor.

props.title: Last name
props.help_text: The last name of the editor.

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the editor.

items.title: Translators
items.help_text: Information on translators, for publications that are translations of publication originally created in another language.

props.title: First name
props.help_text: The first name of the translator.

props.title: Initial
props.help_text: The initials of the translator.

props.title: Last name
props.help_text: The last name of the translator.

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the translator.

items.title: Other contributors
items.help_text: These elements are used to acknowledge contributions to the production of the document, other than the ones for which specific metadata elements are provided (like authors or translators).

props.title: First name
props.help_text: The first name of the contributor.

props.title: Initial
props.help_text: The initials of the contributor.

props.title: Last name
props.help_text: The last name of the contributor. If the contributor is an organization, enter the name of the organization here.

props.title: Affiliation
props.help_text: The affiliation of the contributor.

props.title: Contribution
props.help_text: A brief description of the specific contribution of the person to the document, e.g. “Design of the cover page”, or “Proofreading”.

items.title: Bibliographic citation

props.title: Style
props.help_text: The citation style, e.g. “MLA”, “APA”, or “Chicago”.

props.title: Citation
props.help_text: The citation entered in the style mentioned in "Style". For example (with Style = MLA): Davidson, Russell, and Jean-Yves Duclos. “Statistical Inference for Stochastic Dominance and for the Measurement of Poverty and Inequality.” Econometrica, vol. 68, no. 6, [Wiley, Econometric Society], 2000, pp. 1435–64, http://www.jstor.org/stable/3003995.

items.help_text:
The bibliographic citation provides relevant information about the author and the publication. When using the element "Bibliographic citation", the citation is provided as a single item. It should be provided in a standard style: Modern Language Association (MLA), American Psychological Association (APA), or Chicago. 
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Book title
items.help_text:
Title of a book, part of which is being cited. If you are documenting the book itself, this element will not be used; it is only used when part of a book is being documented.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Chapter
items.help_text:
A chapter (or section) number. This element is only used to document a resource which has been extracted from a book.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Edition
items.help_text:
The edition of a book - for example “Second”. When a book has no edition number/name present, it can be assumed to be a first edition. If the edition is other than the first, information on the edition of the book being documented must be mentioned in the citation. The edition can be identified by a number, a label (such as “Revised edition” or “Abridged edition”), and/or a year. The first letter of the label should be capitalized.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Institution name
items.help_text:
The sponsoring institution of a technical report. For citations of Master’s and Ph.D. thesis, this will be the name of the school.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Journal name
items.help_text:
A journal name. Abbreviations are provided for many journals.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Volume
items.help_text:
The volume of a journal or multi-volume book. Periodical publications, such as scholarly journals, are published on a regular basis in installments that are called issues. A volume usually consists of the issues published during one year.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Number
items.help_text:
The number of a journal, magazine, technical report, or of a work in a series. An issue of a journal or magazine is usually identified by its volume (see previous element) and number; the organization that issues a technical report usually gives it a number; and sometimes books are given numbers in a named series.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Pages
items.help_text:
One or more page numbers or range of numbers, such as 42-111 or 7,41,73-97 or 43+ (the `+’ indicates pages following that don’t form a simple range).
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Publisher name
items.help_text:
The entity responsible for making the resource available. For major publishing houses, the information can be omitted. For small publishers, providing the complete address is recommended. If the company is a university press, the abbreviation UP (for University Press) can be used. The publisher is not stated for journal articles, working papers, and similar types of documents.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Publisher address
items.help_text:
The address of the publisher. For major publishing houses, just the city is given. For small publishers, the complete address can be provided.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Series name
items.help_text:
The name of a series or set of books. When citing an entire book, the title field gives its title and an optional series field gives the name of a series or multi-volume set in which the book is published.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Cross reference
items.help_text:
The catalog identifier (“database key”) of another catalog entry being cross referenced. This element may be used when multiple entries refer to a same publication, to avoid duplication.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Key
items.help_text:
A key is a field used for alphabetizing, cross referencing, and creating a label when the `author’ information is missing.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Organization
items.help_text:
The organization that sponsors a conference or that publishes a manual.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Annotation
items.help_text:
An annotation. This element will not be used by standard bibliography styles like the MLA, APA or Chicago, but may be used by others that produce an annotated bibliography.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: How published
items.help_text:
The "How published" element is used to store the notice for unusual publications. The first word should be capitalized. For example, “WebPage”, or “Distributed at the local tourist office”.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: URL
items.help_text:
The URL of the document, preferably a permanent URL.
Note: The BibTex templates (available at https://www.bibtex.com/format/) provide a useful list of required and optional fields by type of document.

items.title: Document type
items.help_text: This describes the nature of the resource. It is recommended practice to select a value from a controlled vocabulary, which could for example include the following options: "article", "book", "booklet", "collection", "conference proceedings", "manual", "master thesis", "patent", "PhD thesis", "proceedings", "technical report", "working paper", "website", "other". Specialized agencies may want to create their own controlled vocabularies; for example, a national statistical agency may need options like "press release", "methodology document", "protocol", or "yearbook".

items.title: Publication frequency
items.help_text:
Some documents are published regularly. The frequency of publications can be documented using this element. A controlled vocabulary can be provided in user templates, for example the PRISM Publishing Frequency Vocabulary which identifies standard publishing frequencies for a serial or periodical publication with the following options:
- annually (published once a year)
- semiannually (published twice a year)
- quarterly (published every 3 months, or once a quarter)
- bimonthly (published twice a month)
- monthly (published once a month)
- biweekly (published twice a week)
- weekly (published once a week)
- daily (published every day)
- continually (published continually as new content is added; typical of websites and blogs, typically several times a day)
- irregularly (published on an irregular schedule, such as every month except July and August)
- other (published on another schedule not enumerated in this controlled vocabulary)

items.title: Language
items.help_text: The language(s) in which the document is written. For the language codes and names, the use of the ISO 639-2 standard is recommended.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the language.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: The code of the language. The use of ISO 639-2 (the alpha-3 code in Codes for the representation of names of languages) is recommended.

items.title: Description
items.help_text: This element is used to provide a brief description of the document (not an abstract, which would be provided in the field "abstract"). It should not be used to provide content that is contained in other, more specific elements. The "Description" field is a potentially rich source of indexable terms; so care should thus be taken to provide this information when possible. Best practice recommendation for this element is to use full sentences, as description is often used to present information to users to assist in their selection of appropriate resources from a set of search results.

items.title: Abstract
items.help_text: The abstract is a summary of the document, usually about one or two paragraph(s) long (around 150 to 300 words).

items.title: Scope
items.help_text: A textual description of the topics covered in the document, which complements (but does not duplicate) the elements "Description" and "Topics" available in the template.

items.title: Keywords

props.title: Keyword
props.help_text: The keyword (or phrase) itself.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The controlled vocabulary (including version number or date) from which the keyword is extracted, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL of the controlled vocabulary from which the keyword is extracted, if any.

items.help_text: A list of keywords that provide information on the content of the document. Keywords provide a convenient solution to improve the discoverability of the document, as it allows terms and phrases not found in the document itself to be indexed and to make a document discoverable by text-based search engines. A controlled vocabulary can be used (although not required), such as the UNESCO Thesaurus (see http://vocabularies.unesco.org/browser/thesaurus/en/). The list provided here can combine keywords from multiple controlled vocabularies and user-defined keywords.

items.title: Topics

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The unique identifier of the topic. It can be a sequential number, or the ID of the topic in a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Topic
props.help_text: The label of the topic.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: When a hierarchical (nested) controlled vocabulary is used, the "Parent ID" field can be used to indicate a higher-level topic to which this topic belongs.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The specification (name including the version and date) of the controlled vocabulary from which the topic is taken.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: A link (URL) to the controlled vocabulary website.

items.help_text: "Topics" indicate the broad substantive topic(s) that the document covers. A topic classification facilitates referencing and searches in electronic survey catalogs; topics should thus be selected from a standard controlled vocabulary, for example the CESSDA Topics classification (a typology of topics available in 11 languages; see https://vocabularies.cessda.eu/vocabulary/TopicClassification), or the Journal of Economic Literature (JEL) Classification System (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/JEL_classification_codes). The list provided here can combine topics from multiple controlled vocabularies and user-defined topics.

items.title: Themes

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The ID of the theme, taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Theme
props.help_text: The name (label) of the theme, preferably taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: The parent ID of the theme (ID of the item one level up in the hierarchy), if a hierarchical controlled vocabulary is used.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name (including version number) of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL to the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

items.help_text: A list of themes covered by the document. A controlled vocabulary will preferably be used. The list provided here can combine themes from multiple controlled vocabularies and user-defined themes. Note that themes will rarely be used as the elements topics and disciplines are more appropriate for most uses.

items.title: Disciplines

props.title: ID
props.help_text: The ID of the discipline, taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Discipline
props.help_text: The name (label) of the discipline, preferably taken from a controlled vocabulary.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: The parent ID of the discipline(ID of the item one level up in the hierarchy), if a hierarchical controlled vocabulary is used.

props.title: Vocabulary
props.help_text: The name (including version number) of the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL to the controlled vocabulary used, if any.

items.help_text: Information on the academic disciplines related to the content of the document. A controlled vocabulary will preferably be used, for example the one provided by the list of academic fields in Wikipedia (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_academic_fields). The list provided here can combine disciplines from multiple controlled vocabularies and user-defined disciplines.

items.title: Table of contents
items.help_text: The table of content of the document, provided as a single string element, i.e. with no structure (an structured alternative is provided with the field "Table of content (structured)". This element is also a rich source of indexable terms which can contribute to document discoverability; this element (or its alternative "Table of content (structured)" should thus be filled when possible.

items.title: Table of contents (structured)

props.title: ID
props.help_text: A unique identifier for the element of the table of content. For example, the ID for Chapter 1 could be “1” while the ID for section 1 of chapter 1 would be “11”.

props.title: Parent ID
props.help_text: The ID of the parent section (e.g., if the table of content is divided into chapters, themselves divided into sections, the Parent ID of a section would be the ID of the chapter it belongs to).

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The label of this item of the table of content (e.g., the chapter or section title).

items.help_text: This element is used as an alternative to "Table of content" to provide a structured table of content. The element contains a repeatable block of sub-elements which provides the possibility to define a hierarchical structure.

items.title: Countries
items.help_text:
The list of countries (or regions) covered by the document, if applicable. This information is highly relevant and will often be used as a filter (facet) in data catalogs. It is thus a "Recommended" field. Try and extract (possibly using a script that parses the document) information on the countries mentioned in the document. 

When a document is related to a region (not to specific countries), or when it is related to a topic but not a specific geographic area, the "Countries" element  might still be applicable. When a document is related to only part of a country, we still want to capture this information in the metadata. “World” (code WLD) can be entered if the document is related but not specific to countries (for example, a document on “Climate change mitigation”). If a document is not specific to any country, the element "Countries" can be ignored (for example, the user’s guide of a software application). Note that many organizations have their own policies on the naming and spelling of countries/regions/economies/territories, which data curators will have to comply with.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The country/region name. Note that many organizations have their own policies on the naming of countries/regions/economies/territories, which data curators will have to comply with.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: The country/region code. It is recommended to use a standard list of country codes, such as the ISO 3166.

items.title: Geographic areas
items.help_text: A list of geographic areas covered in the document, other than the countries listed in "Countries".

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the geographic area.

props.title: Code
props.help_text: The code of the geographic unit.

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of the the geographic area (e.g., “province”, “state”, “district”, or “town”).

items.title: Bounding box

props.title: West
props.help_text: West longitude of the bounding box.

props.title: East
props.help_text: East longitude of the bounding box.

props.title: South
props.help_text: South latitude of the bounding box.

props.title: North
props.help_text: North latitude of the bounding box.

items.help_text: This element is used to define one or multiple geographic bounding box(es), which are the rectangular fundamental geometric description of the geographic coverage of the data. A bounding box is defined by west and east longitudes and north and south latitudes, and includes the largest geographic extent of the dataset’s geographic coverage. The bounding box provides the geographic coordinates of the top left (north/west) and bottom-right (south/east) corners of a rectangular area. This element can be used in catalogs as the first pass of a coordinate-based search. The valid range of latitude in degrees is -90 and +90 for the southern and northern hemisphere, respectively. Longitude is in the range -180 and +180 specifying coordinates west and east of the Prime Meridian, respectively. This element will rarely be used for documenting publications. Bounding boxes are an optional element, but when a bounding box is defined, all four coordinates are required.

items.title: Spatial coverage
items.help_text: This element provides another field for capturing information on the spatial coverage of a document, which complements the "Countries", "Geographic areas", and "Bounding box" elements. It can be used to qualify the geographic coverage of the document, in the form of a free text. For example, a report on refugee camps in the Cox's Bazar district of Bangladesh would have Bangladesh as reference country, "Cox's Bazar" as a "Geographic area", and "Rohingya's refugee camps" as "Spatial coverage".

items.title: Temporal coverage
items.help_text: Not all documents have a specific time coverage. When they do, it can be specified in this element.

items.title: Status
items.help_text: The status of the document. The status of the document should (but does not have to) be provided using a controlled vocabulary, for example with the following options: "first draft", "draft", "reviewed draft", "final draft", "final". Most documents published in a catalog will likely be "final".

items.title: Rights
items.help_text: A statement on the rights associated with the document (others than the copyright, which should be described in the element "Copyright").

items.title: Copyright
items.help_text: A statement and identifier indicating the legal ownership and rights regarding use and re-use of all or part of the resource. If the document is protected by a copyright, enter the information on the person or organization who owns the rights.

items.title: License
items.help_text: Information on the license(s) attached to the document, which defines the terms of use.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The name of the license (e.g., CC-BY 4.0).

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The URL of the license, where detailed information on the license can be obtained.

items.title: Usage terms
items.help_text: This element is used to provide a description of the legal terms or other conditions that a person or organization who wants to use or reproduce the document has to comply with.

items.title: Disclaimer
items.help_text: A disclaimer limits the liability of the author(s) and/or publisher(s) of the document. A standard legal statement should be used for all documents from a same agency. For example (from the World Bank Policy Research Working Papers): "This work is a product of the staff of The World Bank with external contributions. The findings, interpretations, and conclusions expressed in this work do not necessarily reflect the views of The World Bank, its Board of Executive Directors, or the governments they represent. The World Bank does not guarantee the accuracy of the data included in this work. The boundaries, colors, denominations, and other information shown on any map in this work do not imply any judgment on the part of The World Bank concerning the legal status of any territory or the endorsement or acceptance of such boundaries."

items.title: Security classification
items.help_text: Information on the security classification attached to the document. The different levels of classification indicate the degree of sensitivity of the content of the document. The use of the controlled vocabulary is recommended (the controlled vocabulary must be specific to the organization that curates or disseminates the document), for example with the modalities "public", "internal only", "restricted", "confidential", "strictly confidential".

items.title: Access restrictions
items.help_text: A textual description of access restrictions that apply to the document.

items.title: Pricing
items.help_text: The current price of the document in any defined currency. As this information is subject to regular change, it will often not be included in the document metadata.

items.title: Contacts
items.help_text: Contact information for a person or organization that can be contacted for inquiries related to the document.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: name

props.title: Role
props.help_text: Role

props.title: Email
props.help_text: Email

items.title: Sources

props.title: Origin
props.help_text: For historical materials, information about the origin(s) of the sources and the rules followed in establishing the sources should be specified.

props.title: Characteristics
props.help_text: Characteristics of the source. Assessment of characteristics and quality of source material.

props.title: Documentation
props.help_text: Documentation and access to the source.

items.help_text: This element is used to describe the sources of different types (except data sources, which must be listed in the element "Data sources") that were used in the production of the document.

items.title: Data sources

props.title: Dataset
props.help_text: Name (title) of the dataset used as source. For example: "Bangladesh Demographic and Health Survey 2017-18"

props.title: URL
props.help_text: Link (URL) to the dataset or to a web page describing the dataset. For example: "https://www.dhsprogram.com/methodology/survey/survey-display-536.cfm"

props.title: Note
props.help_text: Additional information on the data source. For example: "Household survey conducted by the National Institute of Population Research and Training, Medical Education and Family Welfare Division and Ministry of Health and Family Welfare. Data and documentation available at https://dhsprogram.com/)"

items.help_text: Used to list the machine-readable data file(s) -if any- that served as the source(s) of data.

items.title: Reproducibility statement
items.help_text: The "Reproducibility statement" is a general statement on reproducibility and replicability of the analysis (including data processing, tabulation, production of visualizations, modeling, etc.) being presented in the document.

items.title: Reproducibility links

props.title: URL
props.help_text: The link to a web page.

props.title: Description
props.help_text: A brief description of the content of the web page.

items.help_text: The "Reproducibility links" provides links to web pages where reproducible materials and the related information can be found.

items.title: Audience
items.help_text: Information on the intended audience for the document, i.e. the category or categories of users for whom the resource is intended in terms of their interest, skills, status, or other.

items.title: Mandate
items.help_text: The legislative or other mandate under which the resource was produced.

items.title: Related resources
items.help_text: References to related resources with a specification of the type of relationship.

props.title: Name
props.help_text: The title or name of the related resource. Recommended practice is to identify the related resource by means of a URL. If this is not possible or feasible, a string conforming to a formal identification system may be provided.

props.title: Type
props.help_text: The type of relationship. The use of a controlled vocabulary is recommended. The Dublin Core proposes the following vocabulary: "isPartOf", "hasPart", "isVersionOf", "isFormatOf", "hasFormat", "references", "isReferencedBy", "isBasedOn", "isBasisFor", "replaces", "isReplacedBy", "requires", "isRequiredBy".

items.title: Notes

props.title: Note
props.help_text: A note, entered as free text.

items.help_text: This field can be used to provide information on the document that does not belong to the other, more specific metadata elements provided in the schema.

props.title: Tag group
props.help_text: The name of a tag group.

props.title: Tag
props.help_text: The tag itself.
